data.title: Allow to name workspaces

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: Testing #33277 It would be nice to be able to associate a label with a workspace. The label can be presented in the window title and in the recently opened list

data.title: High CPU usage by TypingsInstaller
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T18:07:25.676Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
pgsql|dou|0.0.8
EditorConfig|Edi|0.9.4
JSDocTagComplete|Hoo|0.0.2
vscode-esformatter|how|1.5.2
output-colorizer|IBM|0.1.2
vscode-puglint|mrm|2.3.0
code-spell-checker|str|1.3.7

(1 theme extensions excluded)


---

Opening certain projects causes a process to spawn that apparently downloads TS support files. These processes regularly cause extremely high CPU usage over long periods of time. I don't think this is intentional.

The log has a lot of:
```
Response has been sent.
Closing file watchers for project '/dev/null/inferredProject3*'
Closing file watchers for project '/dev/null/inferredProject3*' - done.
Installing typings ["emitter"]
Entry for package 'emitter' does not exist in local types registry - skipping...
All typings are known to be missing or invalid - no need to go any further
```

I'm also seeing this, which looks like an error:
```
Installing typings ["@fairmanager/core-secur","emitter"]
Package '@fairmanager/core-secur' is scoped and currently is not supported
...
Installing typings ["@fairmanager/core-securi","emitter"]
Package '@fairmanager/core-securi' is scoped and currently is not supported
...
Installing typings ["@fairmanager/core-security","emitter"]
Package '@fairmanager/core-security' is scoped and currently is not supported
```
The package in question is named `core-security2`.

data.title: EH Debugging: bogus column numbers
data.body:
testing #33305 on Windows:

- debug TypeScript hello world extension
- set breakpoint in the 'sayHello' command (e.g. line 21)
- F5

Observe: 
when hitting the breakpoint the CALLSTACK views shows column numbers that are way off:

![2017-08-29_10-53-13](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1898161/29812995-d11790a4-8ca8-11e7-84bc-37b3ee85f751.png)

data.title: Icon: does not work well on Windows 7

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
It looks like on Windows 10 the background of the taskbar is always black, so the log works better there. However, see Windows 7:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/900690/29812668-a7a9c29c-8ca7-11e7-8347-a966e9c30c9a.png)

Even worse, the taskbar color is determined from the wallpaper, e.g.:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/900690/29812706-c6e4df0c-8ca7-11e7-835d-0a3f2007f058.png)

Or can be set directly (yes, where the gap is, the logo is):

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/900690/29812767-007e1710-8ca8-11e7-93a3-0b2b543682f0.png)

data.title: Extension Recommendations: Missing telemetry event
data.body:
Testing #33298

> Repeat steps 1 to 3. Close the pop up. Same event should get fired. The customDimenstions.userReaction should have the user reaction

The event doesn't fire when I press the `Close` button.

data.title: SCM: hide views for repositories without changes
data.body:
I am not a big fan of how crowded the SCM view is now looking like by default, even if there are no changes in any of the other repositories:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/900690/29812400-b73ddf64-8ca6-11e7-8e64-925f94f3af35.png)

The additional UI below the actual changes makes me always think there are more changes I need to take care of.

Can we not hide a view when there are no changes? Or collapse it by default?

data.title: Settings editor closes when selecting already selected option
data.body:
Version 1.16.0-insider (1.16.0-insider)
d0d00e882437092f521d2d7893cc56ee296d278f

- open a workspace with one or more workspace folders
- open the settings editor
- using the dropdown, switch to the folder settings of one of the workspace
- open the dropdown again, and select the already checked option
-> setting editor closes

2. open a file under git control

data.title: Windows: new insider icon in small resolution is indistinguishable from stable version
data.body:
As we learned, in small resolution, the new logo looses its border to the right and as such you cannot distinguish the application from stable.

One suggestion is to go back to the green color for insiders.

data.body:
The current icon on mac uses same colors as the sublime and has a very similar shape.
IMHO this is wrong because our icon would make our users think of Sublime.

data.title: Store workspace folder paths in the same format across OS (forward slash)
Makefile colorization: fix old issues and improvement (~4 changes)
data.body:
1. This pull request fixes the following issue: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/25469
2. Additional improvements according to Makefile documentation.

**Before:**
![before](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5967447/29810501-c4c226b6-8ca8-11e7-93a5-7aae78a44281.png)
**After:**
![after](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5967447/29810505-c6ab9de0-8ca8-11e7-95bd-3bbd88d0a67b.png)

**Total list of changes at the moment**:

1. Allow spaces before ifeq, define, endif, ended, else.
2. Handle braces properly inside the variable, e.g. $(info ()()(())).
3. Handle backslash inside end-of-line inside the $(variable).
4. Handle $$ and special variables according to Makefile documentation.

data.title: Debug: Call stack view should use more ellipsis
data.body:
Testing #33305

IMO the behaviour, under tight space constraints, should be:

- First, the line numbers go away
- Then, the file name starts compressing, with ellipsis
- Finally, the same happens to the actual stack frame label

![peek 2017-08-29 09-42](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22350/29809983-71583e70-8c9e-11e7-8753-afdcd34cc326.gif)

data.body:
Version 1.16.0-insider
Commit d0d00e882437092f521d2d7893cc56ee296d278f

- open the SCM viewlet
- The 'Initialize Git Repository' button is gone. All that's there is to install more providers.

data.title: "Select workspace interpreter" takes no effect when under Ubuntu16.04
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version:newest
- OS Version:ubuntu16.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1.type code from terminal
2.ctrl+shift+p and choose “select workspace Interpreter”
3、choose virtual environment of python
4、restart vs code
5、run the code as follows：

import sys
print(sys.prefix)
print(sys.executable)

---------without this line-------------------
vs code will output：
[Running] python "/home/appleyuchi/PycharmProjects/python/csdn_blogs_code/labs/hello2.py"
/usr
/usr/bin/python

[Done] exited with code=0 in 0.132 seconds

All above shows that the option “select workspace Interpreter”doesn‘t take effect，the
python has been used doesn't point to virtualenv。
All above is operated under Ubuntu 16.04，Not under windows
please help，thank you！

data.title: [shaderlab] Update shaderlab grammar
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T18:07:25.676Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.15063
- Extensions: none
---

Fixed by #33317 
The vscode could not highlight builtin shaderlab matrix for unity builtin.
for example for built-in variable unity_ObjectToWorld (introduced by unity v5.4+)

![before](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/21254846/29804599-3b3ad89e-8cb6-11e7-9d12-acc81b9430a7.png)

But, the following built-in variable could be highlighted by default (available in Unity before 5.4)
![bef](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/21254846/29807176-563948b0-8cc5-11e7-819f-49ccbecbb6ee.png)

Waiting for fixing...

data.title: Feature request: Show the title of the integrated terminal
data.body:
At the moment the drop-down in the terminal window only shows the type of the terminal, which become confusing after having many of them:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3614365/29802621-dac4fdd8-8cb9-11e7-873c-c752b560c705.png)

Both cmd and powershell have ways to set their title, can you please display the titles in the drop-down?

E.g., cmd:

    title "new title"

E.g., powershell

    $host.ui.RawUI.WindowTitle = "Changed Title"

data.title: Added tfvars for Terraform to vs-seti-icon-theme.json
data.body: The .tfvars extension for Terraform is a commonly used Terraform extension (https://www.terraform.io/intro/getting-started/variables.html#from-a-file).  This adds the tfvars extension to the icon theme JSON.

data.title: Automatically enable KeyRepeat on MacOS
data.body:
I am crossposting this issue from https://github.com/VSCodeVim/Vim/issues/1983 at the request of @jpoon.

> I don't believe our extension will have the authority to change macos user defaults. Can you cross-post this issue to VSCode?

Following on from https://github.com/VSCodeVim/Vim/issues/1975.

The aim of this issue is to either enable key repeat by default on MacOS, or to more proactively notify MacOS users that they can set this option. This is an issue in the VSCode vim plugin as by default users cannot hold h/j/k/l to navigate.

As I said in https://github.com/VSCodeVim/Vim/issues/1975, even though this is well documented in the VSCode readme, not all users think to check the documentation, and instead assume this is a bug.

From the [README](https://github.com/VSCodeVim/Vim#mac-setup):

> If key repeating isn't working for you, execute this in your Terminal. 
>
> defaults write com.microsoft.VSCode ApplePressAndHoldEnabled -bool false         # For VS Code
> defaults write com.microsoft.VSCodeInsiders ApplePressAndHoldEnabled -bool false # For VS Code Insider
>
> We also recommend going into System Preferences -> Keyboard and cranking up the Key Repeat and Delay Until Repeat settings to improve your speed.

There are a few questions here:

 * Does this impact all MacOS users?
 * Can we programatically set this option on MacOS?
 * Would there be any downside to doing so?
 * If not, can we more proactively notify impacted users that they can easily fix this issue.

If anyone can answer any of those questions, please comment in here.
